title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. To enhance border investigative resources on the Southwest border, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at certain ports, appropriations are authorized for the United States Customs Service as follows: $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. To enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border, investigative resources for anticorruption and efforts against drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, process cargo, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at major land border ports of entry on the Southwest and Northern land borders of the United States, appropriations are authorized for the United States Customs Service as follows: $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for each fiscal year thereafter. To enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border, appropriations are authorized for the Immigration and Naturalization Service for salaries, expenses, and equipment. For fiscal year 1999, $113,604,000 is allocated, increasing to $121,064,000 for fiscal year 2000, with additional funds as needed in subsequent years. Of the amount for fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is designated for the United States Customs Service. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquisition and deployment of narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border, including Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems and mobile truck x-rays. Additional funds are authorized for subsequent years. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service for acquisition and deployment of narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border, including Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, and contraband detection kits. For fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for various contraband detection equipment including portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, and Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals. For fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for various contraband detection equipment including automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, weigh-in-motion sensors, and AM radio systems. For fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for various contraband detection equipment including automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, weigh-in-motion sensors, AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, and spotter camera systems to counter surveillance of Customs inspection activities. For fiscal year 1999, funding is allocated for contraband detection equipment including spotter camera systems, inbound vehicle counters, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader software at ports of entry. Funding for contraband detection equipment in fiscal year 1999 includes $400,000 for license plate reader software at ports of entry and $15,090,000 for narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest land border, including mobile truck x-rays and ultrasonic container inspection units. In fiscal year 1999, funding for contraband detection equipment along the Southwest land border of the United States includes mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System (TECS) terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, and AM radio stations. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funding includes $1,000,000 for remote watch surveillance cameras, $175,000 for AM radio stations, $875,000 for spotter camera systems, and $1,600,000 for narcotics detectors at border patrol checkpoints. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funding includes $4,840,400 for maintenance and support of equipment at border patrol checkpoints for the Customs Service, and $1,509,000 for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, $1,509,000 is allocated for maintenance and support of equipment for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, based on 10 percent of the cost of the equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can use funds for technologically superior equipment other than specified in subsection (b)(1). The Commissioner of Customs can use allocated funds for equipment that is technologically superior and achieves the same results at a lower cost than specified equipment. They can also reallocate up to 10 percent of the specified amount for other equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment at a lower cost than specified in subsections (A) through (R). The Attorney General has similar authority for amounts and equipment specified in subsection (b)(2). The Attorney General has the same authority as the Commissioner of Customs for amounts and equipment specified in subsection (b)(2). $112,844,584 in fiscal year 1999 and $180,910,928 for fiscal year 2000 will be allocated for increasing inspectors and agents on the Southwest and Northern borders during peak hours and enhancing investigative resources. The allocation of funds includes an increase of 285 inspectors and canine enforcement officers for large cargo facilities on the Southwest border, a net increase of 360 special agents and resources for drug distribution centers, and additional resources for screening cargo and reducing waiting times. The allocation of funds includes a net increase of 360 special agents, 40 intelligence analysts, and resources for drug distribution centers, anticorruption efforts, and personnel costs. The allocation of funds includes a net increase of personnel for border patrol checkpoints, canine enforcement vehicles, and inspectors for the Southwest and Northern land borders to enhance investigative resources. The funding allocation includes an increase in personnel, canine enforcement vehicles, and resources for border patrol checkpoints to enhance investigative efforts on the Southwest and Northern borders. Additionally, there will be an increase in intelligence analysts and resources for border patrol sectors focusing on drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations. The funding allocation includes additional resources for border patrol sectors targeting drug smuggling and money-laundering organizations, an increase in personnel for the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Justice for anticorruption efforts, and covering costs related to personnel hiring.
